item.title: Event-Driven .NET: Building a Publish/Subscribe System with RabbitMQ
item.description:
Want to master Clean Architecture? Go here: https://bit.ly/3PupkOJ Want to unlock Modular Monoliths? Go here: https://bit.ly/3SXlzSt Get the source code here: https://www.patreon.com/milanjovanovic
Want to use RabbitMQ in your .NET apps but not sure how to route messages correctly?
In this video, I’ll walk you through key messaging patterns using RabbitMQ + .NET, including:
✅ Competing consumers pattern ✅ Broadcasting messages to multiple consumers ✅ Using queues vs. exchanges ✅ Setting up fan-out, direct, and topic exchanges ✅ Practical RabbitMQ code with the official .NET client ✅ A complete example with a producer, multiple consumers, and a real RabbitMQ instance in Docker ✅ Visual insights using the RabbitMQ Management UI
If you're building distributed systems or microservices with .NET, understanding RabbitMQ exchanges is critical for scalable messaging.
Bonus: I’ll also show you how to structure a robust broker topology using exchanges and queue bindings to scale message delivery cleanly.
Check out my courses: https://www.milanjovanovic.tech/courses
Read my Blog here: https://www.milanjovanovic.tech/blog
Join my weekly .NET newsletter: https://www.milanjovanovic.tech
Chapters 0:00 Competing consumers pattern 3:12 Solving competing consumers? Kinda... 5:54 RabbitMQ Exchanges 8:23 Implementing Fanout Exchanges
item.author: (Milan Jovanović)

item.title: LegoGPT: Generating Physically Stable and Buildable LEGO Designs from Text
item.description: LegoGPT generates a LEGO structure from a user-provided text prompt in an end-to-end manner. Notably, our generated LEGO structure is physically stable and buildable.

item.title: Microservices Are a Tax Your Startup Probably Can’t Afford
item.description: Why splitting your codebase too early can quietly destroy your team’s velocity — and what to do instead. In a startup, your survival depends on how quickly you can iterate, ship features, and deliver value to end-users. This is where the foundational architecture of your startup plays a big role; additionally, things like your tech stack and choice of programming language directly affect your team’s velocity. The wrong architecture, especially premature microservices, can substantially hurt productivity and contribute to missed goals in delivering software.

item.title: Why Your Lambda Functions Need a Structural Makeover
item.description:
Hi, I'm James Eastham, In this video, I'll share how to structure your Lambda functions for modularity and longevity using Ports and Adapters architecture.
Avoid the pitfalls of monolithic code by separating business logic from infrastructure concerns.
Learn why a clean separation of concerns is vital for maintainable and adaptable code, regardless of whether you're using .NET, Node.js, Python, or Rust. By the end, you'll understand how to make your code more testable, scalable, and adaptable to changes in deployment environments.
00:00 Introduction and Initial Setup 00:56 Common Mistakes in Lambda Functions 01:17 Importance of Modularity and Clean Code 01:52 Introduction to Ports and Adapters 02:50 Driving and Driven Adapters Explained 03:56 Applying Ports and Adapters in Lambda 04:43 Practical Example: Recipe API 06:03 Refactoring for Better Code Design 09:12 Benefits of Clean Code and Modularity 11:14 Conclusion and Final Thoughts
item.author: (James Eastham)
